ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to better write and develop arguments.

I developed very strong close-reading and writing skills, definitely can analyze each work and explore the changes in political philosophy across time in this overall very well-taught course. Especially in these times, history and political philosophy become very relevant, so it was very interesting for me to corroborate the mindsets of great historical historians to the problems that plague modern society.

I learned more about liberal political thought and "modern" political thinkers, as well as the history of major events such as the French Revolution. We addressed questions about revolution, the role of political thought, and many more, including criticism of modernity itself. I enjoyed the way the course was reflexive in that way  our later thinkers were very much in dialogue with the thinkers we studied at the beginning of the semester and last year.
a detailed understanding of modern political theory
I developed my reading analysis and comprehension as well as my writing skills.
I gained knowledge of modern political thinkers and modes of thought.

My favorite part of this course was being able to explore in-depth those thinkers which are often skimmed over in high school history or government courses. Being able to place these authors in conversation with each other and see their analysis of questions which are still being explore in contemporary politics was very interesting, and I look forward to being able to revisit this content further in my academic career.
I read the most influential texts in modern historical and political thought and learned to draw connections between them.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Loved it!

strengths - amazing staff, great content, insightful discussions 
weaknesses - workload, definitely became difficult to manage at times

I thought this was an excellent course. The only thing I would improve is integrating some of the smaller readings into our course better. I thought they paired very well with their placement in the syllabus, but some readings, like Hegel or Kant, felt a little gratuitous without extra context.
The course was well-designed. Professor Schillingers reading questions were great guides through the reading.

The discussions were all very intriguing and examined each text deeply, and the lectures were very informative. However, lectures at times were lengthy and posted too late for me to watch them before my first class which was Monday morning, so in the future perhaps lectures could be posted a day or more in advance for students who have monday morning classes.

I can personally say that I struggled with the later portions of the syllabus - though I did the readings and payed attention in class, I still found it hard to grasp the overarching themes of the later authors and their relationships to each other. I think that if we were able to spend more time on those authors or discuss more of the connections between them, I could've gained more from that section.
All the texts we read were interesting and worth reading. The recorded lectures provided a good introduction to the texts, while the seminar discussions allowed for more in-depth analysis.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: More social elements
The H&P profs opted to do audio lectures this semester, but as someone who is not suited to auditory learning, this made things a little difficult without seeing someone speaking/a slide deck.
The live class discussions made it much easier to learn remotely and kept me engaged.

I actually think recorded lectures are superior to those that are live and in-person. I enjoy being able to watch the lectures at my leisure and start/stop them as necessary, although it isn't possible to ask questions. Zoom is obviously not the ideal format for seminars, but it works relatively well and I don't see how it could be improved.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES I LOVED DS
Yes! This is such interesting information and definitely something one should take into account and keep with them as an active citizen in an interconnected world.

H&P is my favorite of the three DS tracksI find the readings fascinating and the discussion more applicable to current events. I also felt like I had the opportunity to improve the thought that goes into my writing a lot this semester.
Yes. Professor Schillinger is an amazing lecturer and discussion leader. He really makes the material come to life.

Yes, the reading selection was a great continuation of the fall semester of DS and having completed the course I found it very rewarding. In addition, all of the discussions and writing feedback helped me to improve greatly as a reader and writer.
If you want an overview of modern political thought and important ideas of the recent centuries you should take this class.

I would recommend this course to any student who wants to understand the origins of the current political systems and ideologies of the West. Reading the texts in chronological order makes it apparent how each thinker builds upon and challenges those who came before them.
